passages.text: European Credit Alpha

We discuss September supply trends in IG, as well as relative trends in financials vs non- financials. In HY, we argue that a wide HY cyclical premium is at odds with both tight spreads and a tight IG cyclical premium.

We are pleased to invite you to our third Hybrids & Capital Conference, a unique event that covers all hybrid capital segments, in London on 24- 25 September. During the two- day event, Barclays will host a schedule of panel discussions with issuers, investors, industry experts, regulators and rating agencies. The agenda will also include a selection of issuers hosting private one- on- one and group meetings with investors. For more details and to register click here.

So long, Summer European credit faces near- term volatility from French politics and elevated IG supply. While a government collapse is possible, credit impact should be contained. We expect CDS indices to outperform cash, and see value in HY cyclicals, especially BBS.

Issuance has picked up again after the summer lull. We expect further acceleration in September but think volumes will be manageable. For E- IG, financials' supply headwind has abated as issuance looks balanced from here. In E- IG, we expect issuance to be skewed towards fins for the rest of the year.

Out of the wods, into cyclicals. 11 HY cyclical risk premia are at a four- year high as spreads approach the tights. Cyclicals now trade wides non- cyclicals, especially for BBS. HY vs IG divergence on cyclical premia creates scope for relative value in HY cyclicals. We screen for attractive long opportunities using our spread model.

This document is intended for institutional investors and is not subject to all of the independence and disclosure standards applicable to debt research reports prepared for retail investors under U.S. FINRA Rule 2242. Barclays trades the securities covered in this report for its own account and on a discretionary basis on behalf of certain clients. Such trading interests may be contrary to the recommendations offered in this report.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 19. Completed: 28- Aug- 25, 15:09 GMT Released: 29- Aug- 25, 04:30 GMT Restricted - External
European Credit - AppendicesFundamentals in focus and reporting calendar. 16We highlight our reporting calendar of upcoming events.

European credit faces near- term volatility from French politics and elevated IG supply. While a government collapse is possible, credit impact should be contained. We expect CDS indices to outperform cash, and see value in HY cyclicals, especially BBs.
European credit markets were jolted out of the sleepy summer haze, with both IG supply picking up post earnings as well as renewed French political volatility.

Starting with politics, in what feels like a repeat of a previous script, Prime Minister Bayrou announced his intention to hold a confidence vote on 8 September to determine if the budget will be approved. With most opposition parties - notably Le Pen's RN - having signalled their likely rejection of confidence in the government, our economists argue the prospect of a government collapse now appears more probable. There were, however, headlines on Thursday about Bayrou calling for negotiations to avoid a no- confidence vote1. Catalysts from here are the vote on 8 September, protests scheduled for the 10th and the Fitch rating review on the 12th.

Even if the government collapses, from a credit perspective we do not see any major impact, as we assume a new prime minister would be appointed and tasked with approving a less ambitious budget. The largest moves have, understandably, been in OATs, while French credit has only marginally underperformed. At a macro level, the French news did lead to SenFin- Main underperformance, helped by a small short- risk base in SenFin, undoing significant SenFin- Main compression over July.

IG supply has been picking up in a meaningful way post earnings, in line with seasonal trends (Figure 1). Based on prior years patterns, supply could remain elevated in IG for up to four weeks, before slowing down. As we discuss in the IG section, based on our FY25 forecasts, we expect around €70bn and €6.5bn of euro and sterling IG issuance in September. For €IG, this has a slight tilt to non- financials (we expect €100bn for the remainder of the year, vs €90bn for financials). For sterling IG, we see financials constituting the bulk of supply.

The combination of French vol and a pick- up in supply has led to widening across European credit (from tight spreads), but with some dispersion in relative moves since the tights (Figure 2). CDS indices have generally underperformed (we suspect negative gamma effects in play, aided by OAT weakness), and HY in general underperformed, undoing some of its outperformance over the summer.

With the roll coming into view and supply ongoing, we think Main, and CDS indices generally, could outperform cash. On the HY side, we note an interesting divergence with the HY cyclical risk premia at a four- year high as spreads approach the tights. This is even more notable as the
cyclical premium in IG credit remains very small. As such, we see value in HY cyclicals, BBS in particular.
FIGURE 1. Seasonal patterns point to 3-4 weeks of elevated IG supply
Source: Bloomberg, Dealogic, Barclays Research
FIGURE 2. Amid general widening over the past two weeks, CDS indices, BBS and corporate hybrids have underperformed
Percentage spread change vs predicted levels based on prior 3yr beta to ECorp Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
European Investment Grade

Issuance has picked up again after the summer lull. We expect further acceleration in September but think volumes will be manageable. For €- IG, financials' supply headwind has abated as issuance looks balanced from here. In €- IG, we expect issuance to be skewed towards fins for the rest of the year.

After a busy May and June, €- IG supply slowed down over the summer in line with seasonal patterns. Supported by light issuance and easing macroeconomic uncertainty, spreads tightened by an impressive 13bp in July. With €- IG trading near the tights, the primary market opened up earlier than in previous years with more than €6bn issued in the week- ending 17 August. The earlier reopening and accelerated activity in the past week has put volumes ahead of our expectations, currently running at €38bn versus our €35bn forecast as of 27 August.

We expect issuance to ramp up in September. Based on our FY 25 forecasts and historical seasonality, we envisage around €70bn of issuance over the month, with non- financials (€35- 40bn) issuing slightly more than financials (€30- 35bn, Figure 1). This would be a busy month but no more so than we have seen in the past, given the €82bn placed in September 2024 for example. Though the risks to our September issuance expectations are skewed to the upside while spreads remain at the tighter end of the range, we do not think supply should pose a problem for the market in general. Volumes are manageable and the market has been digesting supply pretty well, as evidenced by the lack of new issue concession (Figure 2). In our view, the flurry of supply that follows the quieter summer period is well known and should not cause sustained pressure.
FIGURE 1. Monthly supply breakdown
Jan-Aug actual, Sep-Dec forecast. August data until 27 Aug. Source: Dealogic, Barclays Research
FIGURE 2. No new issue concession on offer
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

Financials vs. non- financials: Our full- year forecasts for 2025 pencil in more financial (€395bn) than non- financial (€355) issuance, driven by higher financial redemptions. Year- to- date, financials have outpaced non- financials, having issued \(77\%\) of our FY 25 forecast already, versus \(71\%\) for non- financial issuers. Financials have therefore already effectively overcome the main technical headwind we were expecting them to face vs non- financials. Given that banks have made good progress made on their funding plans, we think they have some flexibility into year- end to be more selective issuers, subject to market conditions.

Maturity preferences: The maturity split of financial issuance year- to- date is in line with long- term averages. Shorter- dated issuance continues to be preferred, with \(60\%\) of financial supply coming inside of the seven- year point. The maturity breakdown of non- financial issuance has been more varied (Figure 3). It has skewed more towards the 5- 7yr bucket year to date, at the expense of longer maturities (10- 15yr).

We think it is interesting that issuance was not termed out given the relative flatness of the spread curve between the 5- 7yr and 10- 15yr buckets, meaning supply may be more indicative of where the demand has been. While the steeper rates curve and thus the steepness of the corporate yield curve could have been a factor, 15yr+ issuance nevertheless remained in line with historical averages - despite yields there being closer to the 2023 highs (Figure 4).
FIGURE 3. Non-financial issuance vs. LT averages
Senior bonds only. Source: Dealogic, Barclays Research
FIGURE 4. Non-financial long-end yields elevated
Senior bonds only. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

Reverse Yankees: We have previously discussed the rebound in reverse Yankee issuance (see Supply: €- IG on track, £- IG falling behind, 27 June 2025). As a share of total, US issuance is running at more than \(16\%\) - a level last seen in 2021. In volume terms, this year has already surpassed the 2024 full- year total (Figure 5). Looking forward, the relative attractiveness of EUR issuance has declined over the summer as USD bonds have outperformed both on a swapped spread and outright yield basis (Figure 6). We therefore do not anticipate a further uptick in the share of reverse Yankee issuance from here, though the still- elevated yield differential should see US issuers continuing to come to Europe.
FIGURE 5. Reverse Yankee issuance has been elevated
Source: Dealogic, Barclays Research
FIGURE 6. Not much between USD and EUR issuance
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

After July disappointed our already modest expectations, August has seen some improvement. A number of issuers have tested the market in the last couple of weeks across financials and non- financials, putting supply on track to meet our expectation of £2.5bn this month.
Financial supply has far outpaced non- financials this year, though non- financials have issued more over the past three months (Figure 7). We have already reflected the slower pace in our

updated FY 25 issuance forecasts (€37.5bn financials, €17.5bn non- financials. See Supply: €- IG on track, €- IG falling behind, 27 June 2025). For financials, the €22.5bn issued year- to- date means there is still a decent amount of wood to chop in the final four months while we need to see less than €5bn of non- financial supply to realise our full- year forecast.

This clearly puts the supply technical in favour of non- financials over financials from here. Taking a look at relative performance thus far, the differential broadly moved sideways until the summer despite the supply imbalance (Figure 8). However, we note that financials have staged a sizeable outperformance over the past couple of months, while supply was relatively light versus non- financials. Of course supply is not the only factor at play, especially as banks saw positive news over the summer, but we see the return of financials out- issuing non- financials as a headwind to further outperformance.

September expectations: We expect €6.5bn of gross supply in September, led by financials (€5bn). As with the €- IG market, tight spreads heighten the risk that supply comes in higher than we anticipate. This is what happened last September where more than €10bn of supply hit the market and pressured spreads wider. This is not our base case but we do think the €- IG market is more vulnerable to being repriced by oversupply than the €- IG market.
FIGURE 7. Financial vs. non-financial supply YTD
August data until 27 Aug. Source: Dealogic, Barclays Research
FIGURE 8. Financials outperformed over the summer
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
FIGURE 9. Week-on-week change in bond and CDS indices
Note: Wednesday-to-Wednesday. Source: Barclays Research
FIGURE 10. CDS-Cash basis
Source: Barclays Research
FIGURE 11. Cross-currency RV (hedged to EUR using xccy basis)
Source: Barclays Research
FIGURE 12. Cross-currency RV (hedged to EUR using 3m FX forwards)
Source: Barclays Research

HY cyclical risk premia are at a four- year high as spreads approach the tights. Cyclicals now trade wide vs non- cyclicals, especially for BBs. HY vs IG divergence on cyclical premia creates scope for relative value in HY cyclicals. We screen for attractive long opportunities using our spread model.

High yield valuations are at an interesting juncture. Spreads have continued to grind tighter and now sit close to post- GFC lows, yet dispersion beneath the surface is elevated (as we discussed previously). This reflects increasingly selective positioning amidst the current uncertainty surrounding the market.

We discussed last week how this dynamic is reflected in CCCs looking attractive vs Bs. This week, we argue that it is also reflected in how the market is pricing in cyclical risk. As shown in Figure 1, the cyclical risk premium is at its highest in the last four years, after being negative for quite some time. In particular in the context of the index spread making tighter tights, this shift warrants a deeper examination of the drivers of elevated cyclical risk premia.
FIGURE 1. The cyclical premium is at its highest in the past four years
Based on a cross- sectional regression of constituents of the eHY index. Source: Barclays Research, Bloomberg

Comparing spread levels for cyclical vs non- cyclical sectors, we show that the spread difference between the two turned positive in the past few months (Figure 2), in contrast to the trend since late 2023 that saw cyclicals trade inside non- cyclicals. Notably, in Figure 3, we observe that the shift is more prominent across BBs than Bs, suggesting investor caution even towards higher- rated credit.
FIGURE 2. Spreads for cyclicals trade wide to non-cyclical sectors...
Source: Barclays Research, Bloomberg
FIGURE 3. ...which is more pronounced in BBs than single-Bs
Source: Barclays Research, Bloomberg

Figure 4 shows the absolute spread levels and historical percentiles for cyclical sectors in the market. We see that, while most of the market including the overall index, is trading close to the tights, some sectors - including Chemicals and Paper - still trade wider to history than their peers. That said, we have recently updated our sector views wherein we discuss our stance towards these sectors combining our expectations for relative valuations with expected returns.
FIGURE 4. Cyclical sector spreads and their historical percentile ranks
Percentile ranks based on a 4-yr horizon Source: Barclays Research, Bloomberg

Moreover, in Figure 5, we compare the cyclical premium across the HY and IG market. While the premium has risen meaningfully for HY, it has been much more stable for IG, underscoring an inherent aversion towards lower- rated credit. We think this divergence creates a good opportunity to look for single- name relative value opportunities within HY cyclicals. We present the cyclical sectors that screen tight/wide in HY vs IG in Figure 6.
FIGURE 5. In contrast to HY, the cyclical premium for IG has been rather stable and even slightly fallen
FIGURE 6. HY vs IG for different cyclical sectors
BasisTights (Since 2021)% RankHY-IG-Div. Man.88621%HY-IG Retail1591451%HY-IG-Transport1148312%HY-IG-Cons. Products15011112%HY-IG Autos148-12033%HY-IG-Airlines1062343%HY-IG-Chemicals33716476%
Percentile ranks based on a 4-yr horizon Source: Barclays Research, Bloomberg
Based on cross-sectional regressions of constituents of the EHY and EIG index. Source: Barclays Research, Bloomberg

Finally, we screen for single- name opportunities using our EHY spread model. Specifically, we look at bonds that are i) part of cyclical sectors, ii) not rated Underweight by our analysts, iii) wide vs the model in absolute, and iv) wide vs model relative to history. We identify the top longs based on this methodology and present them in Figure 7.
FIGURE 7. Top longs based on names that that trade wide to our spread model
Hist Pctile represents the percentile rank of the difference between the market and model spread, measured over a 2-year period Source: Barclays Research, Bloomberg
FIGURE 8. iTraxx Crossover vs. iTraxx Main
FIGURE 9. Pan-Europe HY (ex-financials) spread by rating
Source: S&P Global, Barclays Research. Please click here to see on Barclays Live

European Credit - Appendices
We highlight our reporting calendar of upcoming events.
For our latest EU company rating changes, click here for IG and here for HY. For our sector ratings, click here for IG and here for HY.

Both Aroundtown and Grand City reported valuation gains during H1, bringing headline LTV significantly below policy limits. While both landlords plan to grow, we do not expect move to be swift as EPRA LTV remain high and refinancing is expected to decrease ICR. We remain UW.

Castellum's office exposure and shorter leases pose operational challenges, though these are offset by its lower leverage compared with Balder. We initiate on both issuers at Market Weight. We prefer logistics names P3, CTP and LOGICR, though favour BALDER and CASTSS over GYCGR, HEIBOS and ARNDTN.
Neeraj Kumar discusses takeaways from his recent initiation on Nordic diversified landlords covering: property portfolio; company ratings; hybrids and trade ideas.

KDP announced it will first acquire JDEP in cash for an equity value of EUR15.7bn and then spin off the coffee business by YE26, while targeting IG rating for the two new entities. We analyse pros and cons for bondholders and lower our rating to Market Weight on limited spread upside.
Note: For full disclosures on each covered company, please refer to http://publicresearch.barcap.com

Sectors in U.S. High Grade Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg U.S. Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg U.S. Credit Index.

Sectors in U.S. High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg U.S. High Yield 2% Issuer Capped Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg U.S. High Yield 2% Issuer Capped Credit Index.
Sectors in European High Grade Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European Credit Index.

Sectors in Industrials and Utilities in European High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield 3% Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield 3% Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials.

Sectors in Financials in European High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield Finance Index and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield Finance Index.
Sectors in Asia High Grade Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index.
Sectors in Asia High Yield Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Yield Corporate Credit Index.

Sectors in EEMEA and Latin America Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM USD Corporate and Quasi Sovereign Index. These sectors may contain both High Grade and High Yield issuers.

Overweight (OW): The analyst expects the six- month total return of the debt security subject to this rating to exceed the six- month expected total return of the relevant sector.
Market Weight (MW): The analyst expects the six- month total return of the debt security subject to this rating to be in line with the six- month expected total return of the relevant sector.
Underweight (UW): The analyst expects the six- month total return of the rated debt security subject to this rating to be less than the six- month expected total return of the relevant sector.
Coverage Suspended (CS): Coverage of this issuer has been temporarily suspended.

Not Covered (NC): Barclays' fundamental credit research team does not provide formal, continuous coverage of this issuer and has not assigned a rating to the issuer or its debt securities. Any analysis, opinion or trade recommendation provided on a Not Covered issuer or its debt securities is valid only as of the publication date of this report and there should be no expectation that additional reports relating to the Not Covered issuer or its debt securities will be published thereafter.

Where a recommendation is made at the issuer level, it does not apply to any sanctioned securities, where trading in such securities would be prohibited under applicable law, including sanctions laws and regulations.

\*In EEMEA and Latin America (and in certain other limited instances in other regions), analysts may occasionally rate issuers that are not part of the Bloomberg U.S. Credit Index, the Bloomberg Pan-European Credit Index, the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index or Bloomberg EM USD Corporate and Quasi Sovereign Index. In such cases the rating will reflect the analyst's view of the expected excess return over a six- month period of the issuer's corporate debt securities relative to the expected excess return of the relevant sector, as specified on the report.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated. Nothing in these materials, including any images included therein, is intended to convey, suggest or indicate that Barclays considers or represents any product, service, person or body mentioned in these materials as meeting or qualifying for any ESG or sustainability classification, label or similar standards that may exist under ESG Regimes. Barclays has not conducted any assessment of compliance with ESG Regimes. Parties are reminded to make their own assessments for these purposes.

IRS Circular 230 Prepared Materials Disclaimer: Barclays does not provide tax advice and nothing contained herein should be construed to be tax advice. Please be advised that any discussion of U.S. tax matters contained herein (including any attachments) (i) is not intended or written to be used, and cannot be used, by you for the purpose of avoiding U.S. tax- related penalties; and (ii) was written to support the promotion or marketing of the transactions or other matters addressed herein. Accordingly, you should seek advice based on your particular circumstances from an independent tax advisor.
